full_text:
.NET 10 is officially released! üéâ

Here are the top updates üëá

First, .NET 10 is an LTS (long-term support) release. So we get support for the next 3 years.

üî• Performance improvements

Under the hood, .NET 10 delivers major performance boosts. The JIT compiler has been tuned with new optimizations such as de‚Äëabstraction, smarter inlining heuristics and constant‚Äëfolding, allowing the runtime to do more work at compile‚Äëtime rather than at run‚Äëtime. There are many other optimizations across collections and LINQ, which translate to tangible speedups across everyday workloads.

üöÄ Aspire goes polyglot

Formerly .NET Aspire, Aspire is now a polyglot, developer‚Äëfirst platform for orchestrating front ends, APIs, containers and databases. Version 9.5 introduces a preview of a single‚Äëfile AppHost, letting you define and run your entire distributed application in a single file. The release also debuts a Generative AI visualizer to inspect and debug prompts and responses, plus expanded AI support with typed clients for GitHub Models and Azure AI Foundry and first‚Äëclass OpenAI integration.

üîó EF Core‚Äôs new LeftJoin/RightJoin operators

LINQ‚Äôs lack of a built‚Äëin outer join has long been a pain point. EF Core 10 fixes this by adding LeftJoin and RightJoin operators, so the code now reads exactly like the SQL you intend. For example, you can join products to reviews using LeftJoin() and EF will generate the correct LEFT JOIN statement under the hood. A corresponding RightJoin() keeps all rows from the right side while bringing in matches from the left. These new operators eliminate the verbose GroupJoin + DefaultIfEmpty pattern and make LINQ queries easier to read and maintain.

What's your favorite feature coming in .NET 10?

---

Did you check out the new IExceptionHandler feature?

You have to handle exceptions somehow.

IExceptionHandler implements the "try-" pattern.

You can decide which exceptions to handle.

To tell the middleware you handled the exception, you return true.

So, what makes this so interesting?

You can also chain multiple exception handlers that will run sequentially.

The first one to handle the exception successfully breaks the chain.

Here's how to use this in .NET 10: https://lnkd.in/e9k5yeJ3

It's a way to compose multiple exception handlers.

How do you approach global error handling?

---

full_text:
I failed an interview because I didn't know how locks work in C#.

Read this to make sure it never happens to you.

I've told this story a couple of times before, but it's worth repeating.

I was in an interview some 7-8 years ago, doing a live coding exercise.

I was integrating with a currency conversion API and needed to add caching.

The problem was how this would scale with multiple concurrent requests.

A classic cache stampede problem.

I wanted to prevent this with locking.

Locking allows us to control how many threads can access some piece of code.

Note that I rarely worked with low-level code.

But the company I was interviewing for does.

Of course, they'd have this in the interview process.

Here's the situation:

- I knew I needed a locking mechanism
- But the method was async (oof!)
- So I tried to solve this using the `lock` statement

And that's where it all went to shit...

The `lock` statement doesn't work with async-await.

And it makes sense.

You can't guarantee which thread will complete the method.

So what's the solution?

You need to use an asynchronous synchronization primitive.

Luckily, C # has many to choose from.

Semaphore, SemaphoreSlim, Mutex, Monitor, etc.

Two important remarks:

1) Use a timeout when waiting on the semaphore
2) Always release the lock with a try-finally

Here's a tough question for you.

How would you implement a lock in a database?

If you want to find the answer, go here: https://lnkd.in/eVTMfu-y

Would you have nailed this interview?

---

The riskiest line of code you'll write today is the one without a feature flag.

Fortunately, .NET has you covered right out of the box.

Feature flags are a software development technique that allows you to wrap application features in a conditional statement.

You can then toggle the feature on or off at runtime to control which features are enabled.

.NET already has feature flag support built in.

You can use the IFeatureManager in your code to check whether a feature is enabled.

Want to learn more about using feature flags?

Check out this article: https://lnkd.in/ddxmMg4V

There are many popular services for managing feature flags.

I've used LaunchDarkly often, and recently also PostHog (it offers many more features).

full_text:
Not all Load Balancing strategies are created equal.

If you are using YARP (Yet Another Reverse Proxy) in .NET, you have 5 built-in ways to distribute traffic. But which one should you choose?

Here is the breakdown:

1. RoundRobin: The classic. It cycles through servers evenly. Simple, but it assumes all servers are equally fast.

2. LeastRequests: The smart choice. It sends traffic to the server currently doing the least work.

3. Random: It picks a server at random. Surprisingly effective for high-volume, uniform workloads.

4. PowerOfTwoChoices: The balanced approach. It picks two random servers and chooses the one with fewer requests. It avoids the overhead of checking every server.

5. FirstAlphabetical: The "sticky" one. It always picks the first available server. Good for failover setups, bad for load distribution.

Most people stick with RoundRobin, but switching to LeastRequests can significantly improve tail latency in systems where request times vary.

I dive deeper into how to scale horizontally using YARP here: https://lnkd.in/daDNMpmB

Which strategy is your default choice?

---

full_text:
How did we make a simple idea so complicated?

CQRS is the simplest pattern out there.

First, there was CQS: Command Query Separation.

What does this mean? We split an object's methods into write (command) and read (query) methods.

CQRS is the evolution of CQS. CQRS works on the architectural level. At the same time, CQS works on the method (or class) level.

The CQRS pattern uses separate models for reading and updating data.

This separation can be logical OR physical.

My preferred approach is starting with logical CQRS.

One database + separate flows for writes and reads.

You can design a data model fine-tuned for each operation.

A lot of developers stay away from CQRS because they think it's complex.

The reality is you're probably already applying CQRS principles without knowing it.

Here's a simple implementation: https://lnkd.in/d-qUdpn3

What do you think about the CQRS pattern?

---

full_text:
In .NET, you usually have to choose between Speed and Consistency.

In-Memory Caching (IMemoryCache):
‚úÖ Blazing fast (nanoseconds).
‚ùå Data is stuck on one server. If you have 10 nodes, you have 10 caches.

Distributed Caching (IDistributedCache / Redis):
‚úÖ Shared across all servers. Consistent data.
‚ùå Network latency. Serialization costs. It's slower.

The Solution: HybridCache.

Don't choose one. Use both.

A Hybrid Cache creates a tiered architecture:

- L1 (Local): The app checks RAM first. If it's there, return instantly.
- L2 (Distributed): If missing locally, check Redis.
- Source: If missing in Redis, fetch from DB, then populate both L1 and L2.

While Microsoft is working on a native implementation, I still swear by FusionCache as the most robust, battle-tested library for this.

I wrote a guide on how to set this up properly: https://lnkd.in/d6NKgMVp

Are you currently using just Redis, or a multi-layer cache?

---

full_text:
What is the cleanest way to get configuration values in .NET?

I use the Options pattern.

Here's why you should know about it.

App configuration lives in:

- Environment variables
- (appsettings) JSON files
- User secrets
- Other config providers

You can get individual values using the IConfiguration interface.

But this is error-prone and won't scale, so I don't recommend it.

Instead, I use the Options pattern:

- Create a class to represent the settings
- Bind the class properties to application settings (JSON)
- Consume the Options pattern in my code using IOption

You can also add data annotations to your settings class for simple validation.

Here's how you can implement the Options pattern in .NET: https://lnkd.in/gjVBDHqM

Do you know the difference between IOptions, IOptionsSnapshot and IOptionsMonitor?

---

full_text:
I love working with the Service Discovery library in .NET.

It's a lightweight configuration-based approach.

This actually came out of the effort done in Aspire.

If you're new to this concept, here's a quick breakdown.

Service discovery allows developers to reference external services using logical names instead of physical IP addresses and ports.

There's a centralized store for services to register themselves.

Clients can query the service registry to find the service's physical address.

The service discovery library for .NET is simpler, though.

It still lets you use logical names to refer to external services.

However, the discovery side is "lacking".

You have to specify the physical addresses in the application settings.

Here's a step-by-step tutorial: https://lnkd.in/eX4Wy3jD

You can configure the service URLs during deployment in your CI/CD pipelines.

Or even use a central configuration store (Azure App Configuration) for service discovery URLs.

---

full_text:
The worst kind of bug is the one that explodes 3 days after deployment.

This is the hidden danger of the standard Options Pattern in .NET.

You might bind your appsettings.json to a class, inject it, and everything looks fine. The app starts up perfectly.

But if a required API Key is missing? You won't know until a user triggers that specific feature, and the app crashes.

This is why "Fail Fast" is crucial for configuration.

If your config is invalid, your application should refuse to start. Period.

You can achieve this by extending the Options Pattern with IValidateOptions.

Instead of just binding data, you attach validation logic:

1. Define rules (e.g., "ApiKey cannot be null", "RetryCount must be > 0").
2. Register the validator.
3. If the config breaks the rules, the DI container throws an exception immediately at startup.

I took this a step further and integrated FluentValidation to make the rules cleaner and more expressive.

Here is the complete implementation code: https://lnkd.in/djz5Yfux

---

full_text:
We‚Äôve been faking left joins in LINQ for over a decade.

EF Core 10 finally adds native LeftJoin and RightJoin operators.

No more GroupJoin + DefaultIfEmpty just to express something every SQL dev understands instantly.

In this video, I break down:
- Why left joins in LINQ were always awkward
- What EF Core 10 actually ships (and what it doesn‚Äôt)
- Why this is about readability and intent, not performance
- Whether this change came too late (or right on time)

Same SQL. Much clearer code.

full_text:
Looking for a simple message bus in .NET?

I recommend taking a look at System Threading Channels.

You can implement a simple in-memory message bus using Channels in .NET.

Channels implement the producer-consumer pattern:

- Producers asynchronously produce data
- Consumers asynchronously consume that data

A channel has a Writer and Reader, that you can use to publish and consume messages. respectively.

Here's how you can use this to implement a simple message bus: https://lnkd.in/ekfJZd5n

Remember that this is still an in-memory bus, so it's not reliable.

You can implement resiliency around this, but it only goes so far.

---

full_text:
If you need to run a task "Every Friday at 5 PM," how do you implement it?

A While(true) loop with a Thread.Sleep() is not the answer.

You need a robust scheduler that understands Cron Expressions.

A Cron expression allows you to define complex recurring schedules with a compact string.

For example:

‚Ä¢ 15 10 * * * = 10:15 AM every day.
‚Ä¢ 15 10 * * MON-FRI = 10:15 AM, but only on weekdays.

In the .NET ecosystem, the heavyweight champion for this is Quartz.

It parses these expressions for you and ensures your background services fire exactly when they are supposed to.

I broke down how to configure your first job and trigger in this article: https://lnkd.in/dfy-U7jp

What library do you currently use for background jobs?

---

How do you draw architectural diagrams?

One of the most popular and widely used options is UML.

It's been around for ages, and it works great.

C4 stands for:

It's a lightweight model to describe your architecture.

full_text:
I failed a .NET interview question that looked easy.

‚ÄúAdd caching to an async API.‚Äù

The tricky part isn‚Äôt caching.
It‚Äôs what happens when 50 requests hit the same cold cache at once:
- race conditions
- cache stampedes (thundering herd)
- why ConcurrentDictionary still isn‚Äôt enough
- why you can‚Äôt await inside a lock
- the SemaphoreSlim async-lock pattern (with try/finally, double-check, timeout)
- scaling it with per-key locks to reduce contention

I break it down step-by-step using a currency conversion example, and show the exact refactor path from ‚Äúworks locally‚Äù to ‚Äúworks under load.‚Äù

Watch it here: https://lnkd.in/dyN7_acX

full_text:
We all know the pain of code reviews.

You open a Pull Request (PR). You wait. And when you finally get feedback, it‚Äôs just nitpicks about formatting or style.

That doesn't help you ship better software. It just slows you down.

I‚Äôve been testing out ùóîùòÇùó¥ùó∫ùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùóñùóºùó±ùó≤ and their new Code Review feature. I have to say, it feels different.

Most AI tools only look at the few lines of code you changed. They act like a basic spellchecker.

Augment acts like a Senior Engineer.

I typed auggie review on my PR, saw the little üëÄ emoji pop up, and waited. Here is what surprised me:

1. ùóúùòÅ ùó∏ùóªùóºùòÑùòÄ ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùòÑùóµùóºùóπùó≤ ùóΩùó∂ùó∞ùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤: It looks at your entire repository, not just the file you touched. It caught a breaking change I made that would have broken a different part of the app.

2. ùó°ùóº ùóªùóºùó∂ùòÄùó≤: It didn't nag me about style. It focused on real logic bugs and security risks.

3. ùóúùòÅ ùóπùó≤ùóÆùóøùóªùòÄ ùó∫ùòÜ ùóøùòÇùóπùó≤ùòÄ: You can add a simple YAML file to teach it your team's specific guidelines.

It helps you catch the bad stuff, like edge cases and logic errors, before you merge.

If you want an AI that actually understands how you build software, give this a try.

Check it out here: https://fandf.co/4phaDOt

ùó†ùòÜ ùóÆùó±ùòÉùó∂ùó∞ùó≤: Don't skip the custom code review guidelines file. If you take five minutes to list your team's specific rules, the AI stops guessing and starts reviewing exactly the way you want it to. It saves you from repeating the same comments over and over.

Huge thanks to Augment Code for collaborating on this post with me.

full_text:
Clean code tip:

- Merge nested IF statements into one condition

I often make this simple change to improve code readability.

Clean code principles will make you a better developer.

But what is clean code in the first place?

Clean code is code that's:

- Easy to read
- Easy to maintain
- Easy to understand

Writing clean code is a skill.

It's a skill you can learn and improve with practice.

In the initial example:

- Nesting increases complexity
- Nesting makes the code harder to reason about

The solution is to combine the nested IF statements into a single IF.

Three ways you can do this:

- Write an inline boolean expression
- Expose a method with the expression
- Create a variable with the expression

But this is just the start.

Here are 8 more clean code tips: https://lnkd.in/dt84mr9J

Which solution do you like better?

---

What is Claims Transformation in ASPNET Core?

You can use it to extend your authorization logic by adding dynamic claims at runtime.

If your Identity Provider's access token doesn't perfectly align with your application's internal authorization needs, you can use claims transformation.

Claims transformation allows you to modify the claims before the application uses them for authorization.

You can use this to fill in the missing claims from your database or another source.

Here's why this is helpful: https://lnkd.in/eMsd69UY

Did you run a situation like this in your projects?

Now you know one way to solve it.

full_text:
5 EF Core features you need to know ü¶Ñ

EF Core is fast, but only if you use the right tools.

Here are 5 features that will speed up your data access:

1. Query Splitting: Stops "Cartesian Explosion" by breaking huge JOINs into separate SQL queries.

2. Bulk Updates: ExecuteUpdate() modifies rows directly in the DB. Zero memory allocation.

3. Bulk Deletes: ExecuteDelete() wipes data instantly without fetching it first.

4. Raw SQL: Sometimes LINQ generates bad SQL. Raw SQL lets you take the wheel for complex queries.

5. IgnoreQueryFilters: Perfect for Admin dashboards where you need to see "Soft Deleted" data or tenant-specific records.

Bonus: I covered 5 more advanced features in this article: https://lnkd.in/dxbAfjUR

Which one of these saved your production app?

---

Most people think Redis is just used for caching.

But you can also use it as a vector database.

Here are a few use cases for Redis:

- Counters
- Rate limiting
- Leaderboards
- Session store
- Message queue
- Distributed locking

And of course, Redis as a vector database.

What are vectors?

Vectors are sequences of numbers that represent data.

You use an LLM to generate a vector embedding.

This allows you to do Vector Search: searching based on meaning.

Want to learn more?

Check out this article: https://lnkd.in/dwu4f7dj

This is one of the simplest but very valuable AI features you can add to your applications.

---

Your database isn't slow.

Your indexing strategy is.

Most developers treat SQL indexes like a "magic button". You add one to a column, the query gets faster, and you move on.

But what happens when your table hits 10 million rows and that "magic" disappears?

I just dropped a deep dive into how SQL indexing actually works under the hood.

I took a standard PostgreSQL query from 21ms down to 0.02ms (a 1,000x performance gain) by understanding three core concepts.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/diNSHk3Z

full_text:
Cursor pagination is blazing fast.

But it's not a good solution for every situation. Here's why. üëá

Cursor pagination uses a reference point (cursor) to fetch the next page of results.

This reference point must be a unique identifier or a combination of fields that define the sort order.

My tests showed cursor pagination was 17x faster compared to offset pagination.

So why don't we always use it?

Cursor pagination works particularly well for real-time feeds and infinite scroll interfaces.

If most users start at the first page and rarely visit other pages, offset pagination might be sufficient. This will be the case for many applications.

Want to learn more about cursor pagination?

Here's an implementation guide + performance analysis: https://lnkd.in/eS2h4CgC

Did you ever implement cursor pagination?

---

Did you check out the resilience improvements in .NET 9?

We have two official NuGet packages:

- Microsoft.Extensions.Resilience
- Microsoft.Extensions.Http.Resilience

They're built on top of Polly, so the API should be familiar. You can use them to define resilience policies in C#.

They extend Polly with some useful features. For example, a standard pipeline you can add to HttpClients. There's also an OpenTelemetry integration.

A few strategies that are available out of the box:

- Retries
- Timeouts
- Fallbacks
- Circuit breakers

If this saves you from even one network failure, it'll be worth it.

Implementing resilience in .NET? You better...

Polly is probably your first choice.

And Polly is much faster in V8+.

But why should you care about making your application resilient?

Let's say your services communicate by sending HTTP requests.

HTTP requests can fail because of network or server issues.

These failures can disrupt service availability, especially as dependencies increase. This increases the risk of cascading failures.

Luckily, there's a simple way to solve this in your .NET applications.

Here's how you can make your apps resilient: https://lnkd.in/e39__DXH

Do you use Polly in your applications?

There's also an official resilience library in .NET.

But it's a wrapper around Polly that adds OpenTelemetry on top.

full_text:
How do you handle a transaction that spans 3 different microservices?

You can't use a standard Database Transaction (ACID) because the data lives in different places.

You need a Saga.

And a Saga is essentially just a State Machine with memory.

It tracks the progress of a workflow:

1. Current State: "OrderPlaced"
2. Event: "PaymentReceived"
3. Transition: Move to "OrderPaid" state and send a command to the Shipping Service.

If something fails (e.g., "ShippingFailed"), the State Machine triggers a specific "Compensating Action" to undo the previous steps (e.g., Issue Refund).

It turns chaos into a deterministic workflow.

You can see a full code example of an Order Saga here: https://lnkd.in/d6jY3KaP

Sagas are complex at first, but they are a lifesaver for data consistency.

---

full_text:
I spent 2 days speeding up an API endpoint...

And I made it 15x faster.

The endpoint did heavy calculations and pulled data from several services, so it didn‚Äôt scale.

My process was simple:

- Find the slowest code
- Fix the queries
- Cut external calls
- Add caching last

Measure everything. The slow parts were obvious:

- DB calls inside a loop
- Repeated external calls
- Duplicate calculations

Database round trips cost time, so avoid loops and batch what you can.

Independent service calls? Run them concurrently.

Still slow? Add caching with clear expiration rules (IMemoryCache / IDistributedCache).

For distributed systems, OpenTelemetry makes the bottlenecks visible.

üëâ Here‚Äôs how: https://lnkd.in/dsxuMvmz

What would you do differently?

---

full_text:
Data Annotations are great for simple things.

[Required]? Fine.
[MaxLength(50)]? Sure.

But what happens when you need to validate something against a database?
Or validate based on a configuration setting in appsettings.json?

Data Annotations hit a wall. You can't easily inject dependencies into an Attribute.

This is where FluentValidation shines.

Because your validators are just standard classes registered in the DI container, you can inject anything you need.

Want to check if a CouponCode is valid by calling the IPricingService? Just inject it into the OrderValidator constructor.

It turns validation from a static check into a dynamic, intelligent logic layer.

I explain how to wire this up seamlessly in ASPNET Core here: https://lnkd.in/d9nVR8fu

It is a game changer for complex business rules.

---

full_text:
Most developers get this system design question completely wrong.

And years ago, I was one of them.

The scenario was simple:
A user clicks ‚ÄúGenerate Report.‚Äù
The API takes 5 minutes to finish.
What do you change?

Back then, I tried to ‚Äúoptimize‚Äù the slow part... faster queries, better hardware, parallelization.
None of that solved the real problem.

The issue wasn‚Äôt performance.
It was the architecture.

Here‚Äôs what I learned:

‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt run long tasks in an HTTP request
‚Ä¢ Use a queue and a background worker
‚Ä¢ Return 202 Accepted instead of blocking
‚Ä¢ Store the final file in object storage
‚Ä¢ Notify the user when the work is done (SignalR / email / polling)

This simple question changed how I think about system design.
It taught me to design workflows, not endpoints.

I recorded a full breakdown here: https://lnkd.in/etjZHbqA

full_text:
You thought the Outbox pattern was great for consistency.

You didn't realize it was also the slowest part of your microservices architecture.

Don't let it kill your performance.

Here are 4 ways to scale it up:

1. ùó¢ùóΩùòÅùó∂ùó∫ùó∂ùòáùó≤ ùó•ùó≤ùóÆùó±ùòÄ: Index your status columns. Queries must be instant.

2. ùóïùóÆùòÅùó∞ùóµ ùó®ùóΩùó±ùóÆùòÅùó≤ùòÄ: Don't update row-by-row. Update statuses in one go.

3. ùóïùóÆùòÅùó∞ùóµ ùó£ùòÇùóØùóπùó∂ùòÄùóµùó∂ùóªùó¥: Network latency kills speed. Send messages to the broker in groups.

4. ùó¶ùó∞ùóÆùóπùó≤ ùó™ùóºùóøùó∏ùó≤ùóøùòÄ: One processor isn't enough. Run multiple instances in parallel.

I wrote a guide on exactly how to implement this.

Read it here: https://lnkd.in/dcwQT52Q

P.S. If you scale out workers (Step 4), watch out for ordering. Parallel workers can process events out of sequence. Use partitioning to keep related messages in order.
